image.altText: A teenage girl looks at her phone.

props.synopsis: The NT has joined Queensland and NSW in enacting posting and boasting laws but experts worry the changes will not reduce crime, while disproportionately targeting Indigenous youth.

title.children: NT joins youth crime social media crackdown, but a Darwin dad says the new laws miss the point

image.altText: Anna Torv as Emily Lawson wearing a cowboy hat outside on dry land, behind a fence

props.synopsis: Generational clashes threaten to tear apart a family dynasty in Netflix's Territory, set in Australia's Northern Territory.

title.children: Netflix's Territory zeroes in on dysfunctional family dynasty

image.altText: Farmer standing in a field with a phone.

props.synopsis: There are concerns thousands of phones, medical devices, mobile phone boosters in cars, location devices in trucks and farm equipment may stop working.Â

title.children: The 3G network is about to shut down for good, so what will stop working from Monday?

image.altText: Matt Wright walks out of court holding his wife's hand as a press pack surrounds the couple.

props.synopsis: Wild Croc Territory star Matt Wright fronted court in Darwin on Thursday alongside his wife, Kaia Wright, ahead of a highly-anticipated jury trial in 2025.

title.children: Netflix star Matt Wright faces pre-trial hearing in NT Supreme Court ahead of 2025 jury trial

image.altText: Girl wearing violet dress and white paint holding stick in a forest.

props.synopsis: A recent report has called for a new First Nations tourism body. Those on the ground know the challenges faced by budding business owners.

title.children: A conversation with elders sparked an idea to share culture with visitors, but not without its challenges

props.synopsis: As the mercury continues to rise, crews are on stand-by to tackle worsening conditions.Â

title.children: Outback city briefly holds title of most polluted in the world after months of bushfires

image.altText: A woman stands in the desert next to a car with luggage stacked on top. She wears a red tracksuit

props.synopsis: Directed and co-created by Dylan River, Thou Shalt Not Steal is a zippy Western set around Alice Springs, with plenty of twists and laughs.

title.children: Thou Shalt Not Steal is the razor-sharp Indigenous comedy its star has been waiting for

image.altText: dead and dying trees on Groote Eylandt.

props.synopsis: It's feared damage to the environment near a manganese mine on the island may have been caused by the dewatering of mining pits that were flooded by Cyclone Megan in March.

title.children: Vegetation dieback near South32's Groote Eylandt mine under investigation

image.altText: The backs of a woman and a man looking at a body of water.

props.synopsis: A judge has handed down the largest fine ever under the NT's sacred site laws after a sensitive men's site was damaged at Gunlom Falls in Kakadu National Park.

title.children: Gunlom Falls to reopen to tourists after historic fine handed down over sacred site damage

image.altText: A screengrab of a webpage showing flights over the Middle East.

props.synopsis: As Israel and Iran trade blows in the Middle East, commercial aircraft traversing the region are doing so through fewer corridors to avoid getting caught in the crossfire.

title.children: Missiles flying between Israel and Iran have the aviation industry concerned about getting caught in the crossfire

image.altText: A half broken bridge on a river after it collapsed during floods

props.synopsis: As one of the deadliest typhoons in decades ripped through Vietnam, a harrowing video of a bridge collapsing emerged on social media. And while the storm dealt the final blow to the bridge, it may not be the only thing responsible for the tragedy.

title.children: The sand mines, the typhoon and the deadly bridge collapse

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

props.synopsis: If Donald Trump wins the US presidency on November 5, his victory will have profound implications for other countries on many fronts. Not least of them will be climate change policy.

title.children: When it comes to climate, Labor is keeping an eye on Washington before it looks to Paris

image.altText: truck into house

props.synopsis: Emergency services were called to reports a truck veered from the road and crashed into a house on the Princes Highway just after 7am. A man and woman in their 80s inside the house died at the scene.

title.children: Two people killed in bedroom of their home after truck veers off highway in Victoria's south-west

image.altText: A road and footpath with a flood marker.

props.synopsis: The father and his son were riding e-bikes along a footpath in Robina on Wednesday night when a car left the road and struck them. They both sustained life-threatening injuries, and the boy later died in hospital.

title.children: Boy, 9, dies in hospital after being struck by car while riding e-bike with father on Gold Coast footpath

image.altText: A composite image of Erik Menendez and Lyle Menendez as middle-aged men

props.synopsis: Erik and Lyle Menendez could be re-sentenced more than 35 years after killing their parents, a move that could be the first step towards their release.

title.children: Menendez brothers recommended for re-sentencing 35 years after murdering parents

image.altText: A render of a ship's cabin with large rectangular porthole, beige couch and dog bed.

props.synopsis: Tasmania finds itself in a farcical position where the brand-new Spirit of Tasmania ferries it purchased may end up being hand-me-downs by the time they reach the state's shores.

title.children: Tasmanians will have to sit back and watch someone else use their $850m brand-new Spirit ferries

image.altText: smart phone with meta logo on it in front of blue background with facebook logo

props.synopsis: A tech tax might be the federal governmentâs path out of a six-month stalemate with Meta over the companyâs refusal to pay for Australian news, writes Ange Lavoipierre.

title.children: Could Australia flip the table on Meta with a tech tax?

image.altText: People wearing black clothing holding union signs and placards urging Qantas to pay workers more money.

props.synopsis: Qantas shares touch a record high as it holds its annual meeting under the cloud of an engineer's strike, but avoids a board spill. WiseTech shares lead the ASX higher after the company's founder stands down as CEO. Follow the day's events on the ABC News live markets blog. Â

title.children: Qantas shares touch record high as airline avoids board spill, ASX rallies led by WiseTech

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Qantas avoids second strike and board spill
'You're not his parent': Qantas shareholder's pointed exchange with chair
'I feel the ghost of Alan Joyce in the room'

image.altText: A middle-aged man with dark hair takes a selfie among a crowd of people.

props.synopsis: Indonesia is one of Australia's biggest customers for wheat, red meat and live cattle but new president Prabowo Subianto wants the nation to be food self-sufficient within five years.

title.children: 'World's food barn': What does Indonesia's plan mean for Aussie farmers?

image.altText: A booklet being held that says a fresh start for queensland

props.synopsis: Keeping costings under wraps for so long is about mitigating collateral damage, but there was nothing in the numbers from both sides in Queensland likely to change opinions.

title.children: At the 11th hour, one major Queensland political party finally revealed its election costings

image.altText: Jad is at the front of a hidden cave, with a friend. He's not wearing a shirt, and swimming shorts.

props.synopsis: Lebanese people are coming together to help house and feed the 1.2 million displaced people in Lebanon, as the country marks 30 days of war. From Australia to the heart of Beirut, they're uniting together to help the country and its people.

title.children: Jad used to chase waterfalls in Lebanon. Now he's collecting donations to help 1.2 million displaced people

image.altText: Aurizon coal train generic shot

props.synopsis: Whyalla steelworks owner Sanjeev Gupta is facing another major challenge, with rail company Aurizon suspending some of its services for GFG Alliance over unpaid debts.

title.children: Rail operator Aurizon suspends services for GFG Alliance over unpaid debts

image.altText: A woman in full personal protective equipment holding flasks containing pink fluid in a laboratory.

props.synopsis: The Alfred Hospital hosts one of a handful of labs around Australia working on engineered skin, a promising therapy that uses lab-grown cells suspended in sheets that can be grafted onto deep burns.

title.children: Lab-made skin grown from a patient's own cells is being used in a new hospital trial

image.altText: King Charles III chats with owner of alpaca.

props.synopsis: It's that time of the week again. Think you've been paying attention to the news?Â

title.children: Weekly news quiz: King Charles gets sneezed on, a strong man's secret hobby and Donald Trump's drive-thru

image.altText: A man holding a small device to take wind readings.

props.synopsis: An independent odour consultant is patrolling the streets of Kalgoorlie-Boulder, looking for the source of a foul smell residents say is impacting their quality of life.Â

title.children: Outback city calls in specialists to deal with putrefying stench

image.altText: A man crosses a flooded rice field during rains.

props.synopsis: Tropical Storm Trami kills dozens of people and forces more than 150,000 to flee their homes in the Philippines, according to local officials.

title.children: Over 150,000 driven from homes, 26 dead after Tropical Storm Trami rips through Philippines

image.altText: Max Verstappen and Lando Norris talking in the pit lane after a qualifying session, still in racing suits

props.synopsis: Max Verstappen may have been able to halt the charge of Lando Norris last time out, but a controversial end at the United States Grand Prix has added more vigour to an already ambitious Brit.

title.children: Verstappen and Norris poised for Mexican standoff after controversial end in Texas

image.altText: Large submarine

props.synopsis: The latest in autonomous marine technology has been showcased during secretive AUKUS exercises on the NSW south coast with defence officials signalling Japan could soon be involved in the maritime activity.

title.children: Japanese officials observe secretive Jervis Bay exercises ahead of likely AUKUS invitation

image.altText: First Nations DV announcement

props.synopsis: This community organisation is helping women spot the signs their relationship might be in danger. Here's how you can too.

title.children: How to spot the early warning signs in your relationship

image.altText: an 18-year-old woman and man in his 50s inside a car looking at the camera smiling

props.synopsis: Cars are safer than ever, but the country's road toll is still increasing. Race car driver-turned-instructor Paul Morris says teaching road safety skills in schools could be the answer.

title.children: Australia's road toll is getting worse. Is the answer learning to drive at school?

image.altText: Barbed wire and a high fence pictured against a sunset

props.synopsis: Overcrowding forces dozens of prisoners at two of Perth's largest jails to sleep on mattresses on the floor in "Dickensian" conditions.

title.children: Bed shortages force prisoners to sleep on mattresses on floors of Perth's jails, as fears of rising tensions grow

image.altText: Adelaide United assistant coach Travis Dodd and defender Bailey O'Neil

props.synopsis: The current A-League Men's competition has less than a handful of Indigenous players, but emerging talent Bailey O'Neil and mentor Travis Dodd want to "get that ball rolling" when it comes to improving pathways.

title.children: Bailey O'Neil is one of just three Indigenous players in the A-League Men â he hopes to inspire more

image.altText: Promo photo of triple j Breafkast hosts Adam Specner & Wil Anderson

props.synopsis: Twenty years after their iconic triple j Breakfast run, the broadcasting duo discuss their reunion tour. They'll revisit music and yarns from the era and reconnect with listeners so they "can remember what happened".

title.children: Adam & Wil reflect on the music, mateship and mayhem of their memorable triple j era
